Produces maltose (and dextrins) from starch (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Identify the three classes of proteases involved in protein digestion and state their actions. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Endopeptidases hydrolyse peptide bonds within the polypeptide (1 mark)
Exopeptidases remove terminal amino acids from ends (1 mark)
Dipeptidases hydrolyse dipeptides into amino acids (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Explain the role of bile salts in lipid digestion. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Emulsify triglyceride droplets into smaller droplets (1 mark)
Increase surface area for lipase action (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: What are micelles and how do they aid lipid absorption? [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Tiny aggregates of fatty acids, monoglycerides and bile salts (1 mark)
Transport lipid digestion products to brush border (1 mark)
Release monomers that diffuse into epithelial cells (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Outline the digestion of starch from mouth to small intestine. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Salivary amylase begins hydrolysis of starch to maltose (1 mark)
Stomach acid inactivates salivary amylase; no carbohydrate digestion in stomach (1 mark)
Pancreatic amylase in small intestine continues starch → maltose (1 mark)
Brush-border maltase hydrolyses maltose → glucose (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Describe sodium–glucose co-transport in the ileum. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Basolateral Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase pumps Na⁺ out, lowering intracellular Na⁺ (1 mark)
Na⁺ enters from lumen via SGLT with glucose down Na⁺ gradient (1 mark)
Glucose accumulates in cell then exits via GLUT to blood (1 mark)
Blood flow maintains steep concentration gradients (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: How are amino acids absorbed by ileum epithelial cells? [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Co-transport with Na⁺ across apical membrane (1 mark)
Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase maintains Na⁺ gradient (1 mark)
Amino acids exit basolaterally by facilitated diffusion to capillaries (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Explain how triglycerides are absorbed and transported from epithelial cells. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Fatty acids/monoglycerides diffuse in and are re-esterified to triglycerides (1 mark)
Combine with proteins, cholesterol and phospholipids to form chylomicrons (1 mark)
Chylomicrons are exocytosed into lacteals (lymphatic vessels) (1 mark)
Travel via lymph to bloodstream at thoracic duct (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: State the role of lacteals and the lymphatic system in lipid transport. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Lacteals receive chylomicrons from epithelial cells (1 mark)
Lymphatic vessels deliver them to the bloodstream for distribution (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Give one structural adaptation of the ileum that increases absorption and explain its effect. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Villi/microvilli greatly increase surface area (1 mark)
Increases diffusion and transporter density, enhancing uptake (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: What are brush-border enzymes and give two examples with their substrates. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Enzymes embedded in microvillus membranes of enterocytes (1 mark)
Maltase: maltose → glucose (1 mark)
Dipeptidase: dipeptides → amino acids (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Explain how endopeptidases and exopeptidases act synergistically. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Endopeptidases create more peptide ends by cutting internal bonds (1 mark)
Increases substrate availability for exopeptidases (1 mark)
Together accelerate overall protein digestion (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Why does emulsification increase the rate of lipid digestion? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Breaks fat into many small droplets (1 mark)
Larger total surface area for lipase to act (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Describe how chylomicrons are formed inside enterocytes. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Re-esterified triglycerides packaged with phospholipids and cholesterol (1 mark)
Apolipoproteins added in smooth ER/Golgi (1 mark)
Assembled lipoprotein particles (chylomicrons) formed for exocytosis (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Compare absorption routes of glucose/galactose and fructose in the small intestine. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Glucose/galactose via Na⁺-dependent SGLT at apical membrane (1 mark)
Fructose via GLUT5 facilitated diffusion at apical membrane (1 mark)
All exit via basolateral GLUT transporters to blood (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: How does the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase indirectly drive nutrient uptake? [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Pumps Na⁺ out of enterocytes using ATP (1 mark)
Creates low intracellular Na⁺ and electrochemical gradient (1 mark)
Na⁺ influx powers co-transport of glucose/amino acids (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Trace the movement of fatty acids and monoglycerides from lumen to blood. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Micelles deliver monomers to brush border for diffusion into cells (1 mark)
Re-esterification to triglycerides within enterocyte (1 mark)
Formation of chylomicrons and entry into lacteals (1 mark)
Lymphatic transport → venous blood via thoracic duct (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Explain how coeliac disease (villous atrophy) reduces nutrient absorption. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Loss/flattening of villi and microvilli reduces surface area (1 mark)
Decreased brush-border enzyme activity/transporters (1 mark)
Leads to malabsorption and nutrient deficiencies (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Describe lactase deficiency and its digestive consequences. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Insufficient brush-border lactase to hydrolyse lactose (1 mark)
Lactose remains in lumen causing osmotic water retention (1 mark)
Bacterial fermentation → gas, bloating and diarrhoea (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Outline enterohepatic circulation of bile salts. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Bile salts secreted into small intestine to aid lipid digestion (1 mark)
Reabsorbed in the ileum into portal blood (1 mark)
Returned to liver for recycling/secretion (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Differentiate peristalsis from segmentation in the small intestine. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Peristalsis: coordinated waves propel chyme along gut (1 mark)
Segmentation: rhythmic contractions mix contents locally (1 mark)
Segmentation enhances contact with mucosa for absorption (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Explain how water is absorbed in the small and large intestine. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Water follows osmotic gradients created by solute absorption (1 mark)
Na⁺, glucose and amino acid uptake lowers luminal water potential (1 mark)
Small intestine absorbs majority via osmosis through tight junctions and cells (1 mark)
Colon reclaims additional water/electrolytes to form faeces (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Describe the role of the pancreas in digestion and its regulation. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Secretes digestive enzymes (amylase, lipase, proteases) into duodenum (1 mark)
Secretes bicarbonate to neutralise gastric acid (1 mark)
CCK stimulates enzyme secretion in response to fats/proteins (1 mark)
Secretin stimulates bicarbonate secretion in response to acid (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Summarise gastric digestion and protection of the stomach lining. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: HCl denatures proteins and provides acidic pH for pepsin (1 mark)
Pepsin (from pepsinogen) begins protein digestion (1 mark)
Mucus-bicarbonate barrier protects epithelium (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: How is trypsinogen safely activated and why are zymogens important? [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Enteropeptidase (enterokinase) activates trypsinogen to trypsin (1 mark)
Trypsin then activates other pancreatic zymogens (1 mark)
Zymogens prevent autodigestion of pancreas and ducts (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Detail the full pathway of lipid digestion and absorption from duodenum to circulation. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Bile salts emulsify fats into small droplets (1 mark)
Pancreatic lipase hydrolyses triglycerides → monoglycerides + fatty acids (1 mark)
Micelles ferry products to brush border (1 mark)
Diffusion into enterocytes and re-esterification to triglycerides (1 mark)
Assembly into chylomicrons and exocytosis to lacteals (1 mark)
Lymphatic transport to bloodstream via thoracic duct (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: List five villus/enterocyte adaptations that maximise absorption. [5 marks]
mark_scheme: Large surface area from villi and microvilli (1 mark)
Thin epithelium/short diffusion pathway (1 mark)
Rich capillary network to maintain gradients (1 mark)
Lacteals for lipid transport (1 mark)
High density of transporters/brush-border enzymes (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: State chemical tests relevant to digestion practicals for starch, reducing sugars, protein and lipids. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Starch: iodine turns blue-black (1 mark)
Reducing sugars: Benedict’s reagent forms brick-red precipitate on heating (1 mark)
Protein: Biuret test turns purple (1 mark)
Lipids: emulsion test forms milky emulsion with ethanol and water (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Predict the effect of blocking apical SGLT transporters on glucose and water absorption. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Reduced glucose uptake into enterocytes (1 mark)
Less solute-driven water absorption (1 mark)
More glucose remains in lumen increasing osmotic water retention (1 mark)
Leads to diarrhoea/poor hydration (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Why do oral rehydration solutions contain both glucose and salts? [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Glucose facilitates Na⁺ uptake via SGLT (1 mark)
Na⁺ and glucose absorption drives water uptake osmotically (1 mark)
Replaces lost electrolytes and fluids effectively (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: How do short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) differ from long-chain fatty acids in absorption? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: SCFAs are more water soluble and can diffuse directly into capillaries (1 mark)
Long-chain fatty acids enter via micelles/chylomicrons into lacteals (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: State the role of goblet cells and mucus in the small intestine. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Goblet cells secrete mucus (1 mark)
Mucus lubricates and protects epithelium during digestion (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Explain how enterocytes maintain a steep gradient for glucose absorption. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Basolateral GLUT rapidly exports glucose to blood (1 mark)
Dense capillary flow removes glucose maintaining low interstitial concentration (1 mark)
Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase maintains Na⁺ gradient driving continued co-transport (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: What is the function of the hepatic portal vein in assimilation after absorption? [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Transports absorbed sugars and amino acids from gut to liver (1 mark)
Liver regulates blood nutrient levels (storage/conversion) (1 mark)
Detoxifies absorbed substances before systemic circulation (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Qualitatively predict the effect on passive diffusion of glucose if apical surface area increases by 50% while the concentration gradient doubles. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Rate ∝ surface area × concentration gradient (1 mark)
Overall diffusion potential increases threefold (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Suggest consequences of pancreatic lipase deficiency on stool and nutrition. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Poor triglyceride digestion leading to steatorrhoea (fatty stools) (1 mark)
Reduced absorption of fat and fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) (1 mark)
Weight loss/energy deficiency despite intake (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Why is bicarbonate in pancreatic juice important for digestion in the duodenum? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Neutralises acidic chyme from stomach (1 mark)
Provides optimal pH for pancreatic enzymes (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Explain how cholera toxin causes profuse watery diarrhoea in terms of intestinal transport. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Toxin elevates intracellular cAMP in enterocytes (1 mark)
Stimulates CFTR Cl⁻ secretion into lumen (1 mark)
Na⁺ and water follow osmotically/electrochemically (1 mark)
Massive fluid loss overwhelms absorption mechanisms (1 mark)

3.3.3 Digestion and absorption.question: Distinguish micelle-mediated delivery from simple diffusion of lipids at the brush border. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Micelles concentrate lipids and shuttle them through unstirred water layer (1 mark)
Allow repeated delivery/release near membrane (1 mark)
Simple diffusion relies on random collision and solubility alone (1 mark)
Micelles markedly increase effective local concentration and rate (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Define mass transport in multicellular organisms. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Bulk movement of substances over long distances to supply cells and remove wastes (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Name the three main types of blood vessel and state one function of each. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Arteries: carry blood away from the heart at high pressure (1 mark)
Veins: return blood to the heart at low pressure (1 mark)
Capillaries: exchange substances between blood and tissues (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Give three structural adaptations of arteries that suit them to their function. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Thick elastic walls to withstand and smooth pressure surges (1 mark)
Narrow lumen to maintain high pressure (1 mark)
Muscular layer to redistribute blood by vasoconstriction/dilation (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Explain how veins are adapted to aid venous return. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Wide lumen and thin walls reduce resistance (1 mark)
Semi-lunar valves and skeletal muscle pump prevent backflow and aid flow (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Describe two features of capillaries that facilitate exchange. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Walls one cell thick for short diffusion distance (1 mark)
Extensive branching provides large surface area and low blood velocity (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Outline how tissue fluid is formed at the arterial end of a capillary bed. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: High hydrostatic pressure forces plasma out of capillaries (1 mark)
Plasma proteins remain, lowering water potential inside capillary (1 mark)
Fluid and small solutes move into the tissue spaces (ultrafiltration) (1 mark)
Cells exchange gases and nutrients with tissue fluid (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: What happens to most tissue fluid at the venous end of capillaries and why? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: It re-enters capillaries by osmosis (1 mark)
Lower water potential in capillary due to plasma proteins draws water back (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: State two roles of the lymphatic system in mass transport. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Returns excess tissue fluid to the bloodstream (1 mark)
Transports absorbed lipids (as chylomicrons) from the intestine (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Name the three phases of the cardiac cycle. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Atrial systole, ventricular systole, diastole (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Explain the function of atrioventricular (AV) and semilunar (SL) valves during the cardiac cycle. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: AV valves open when atrial pressure exceeds ventricular pressure to allow filling (1 mark)
AV valves close when ventricular pressure exceeds atrial pressure to prevent backflow (1 mark)
SL valves open when ventricular pressure exceeds arterial pressure and close as ventricles relax (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Give the equation for cardiac output and define each term. [2 marks]

Stroke volume is blood pumped per beat; heart rate is beats per minute (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Explain why cardiac output increases during exercise. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Sympathetic stimulation increases heart rate (1 mark)
Increased venous return increases stroke volume (Starling mechanism) (1 mark)
Greater metabolic demand requires higher oxygen and nutrient delivery (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Describe the structure of haemoglobin. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Globular protein with four polypeptide chains (quaternary structure) (1 mark)
Each chain contains a haem group that binds one O2 molecule (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Explain cooperative binding of oxygen by haemoglobin and its effect on the dissociation curve. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Binding of first O2 alters Hb shape (conformational change) (1 mark)
Increases affinity at remaining binding sites (1 mark)
Produces a sigmoidal (S-shaped) dissociation curve (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: What is the Bohr effect and why is it beneficial in active tissues? [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Raised CO2 lowers blood pH (1 mark)
Lower pH decreases Hb affinity for O2 (curve shifts right) (1 mark)
Promotes O2 unloading where respiration is high (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Compare fetal haemoglobin with adult haemoglobin. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Fetal Hb has higher affinity for O2 than adult Hb (left-shifted curve) (1 mark)
Allows effective uptake of O2 from maternal blood in placenta (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: State two factors (other than CO2) that shift the oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve to the right. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Increased temperature (1 mark)
Increased 2,3-BPG/DPG concentration (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Explain how a small mammal’s haemoglobin is typically adapted and why. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Right-shifted curve/lower affinity haemoglobin (1 mark)
Facilitates O2 unloading to meet high metabolic rate (1 mark)
Due to higher temperature/2,3-BPG levels in tissues (1 mark)

Equivalent to 5.25 L min⁻1 (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: A capillary has hydrostatic pressure 35 mmHg (arterial end) and 15 mmHg (venous end); plasma oncotic pressure is 25 mmHg. Predict net movement at each end with brief reasons. [4 marks]

Venous end: 15 − 25 = −10 mmHg net reabsorption in (1 mark)
Filtration driven by hydrostatic pressure (1 mark)
Reabsorption driven by oncotic (colloid osmotic) pressure (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Explain why severe protein malnutrition can cause oedema. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Reduced plasma proteins lower oncotic pressure (1 mark)
Less reabsorption at venous end so fluid accumulates in tissues (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Name the two major plant transport tissues and their transported materials. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Xylem: transports water and mineral ions (1 mark)
Phloem: transports assimilates, mainly sucrose (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Describe two structural adaptations of xylem vessels for water transport. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Dead, hollow cells form continuous tubes with low resistance (1 mark)
Lignified walls resist collapse under tension (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Outline the cohesion–tension mechanism for xylem transport. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Transpiration from leaves pulls water from xylem (1 mark)
Cohesion between water molecules maintains a continuous column (1 mark)
Adhesion to xylem walls aids ascent against gravity (1 mark)
Results in negative pressure (tension) within xylem (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Give two pieces of evidence supporting cohesion–tension. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Tree trunk diameter decreases in daylight when transpiration is high (1 mark)
Air entering xylem breaks the column and stops transport (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: State three environmental factors that affect transpiration rate. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Light intensity (via stomatal opening) (1 mark)
Temperature (affects evaporation and diffusion) (1 mark)
Wind speed or humidity (alters diffusion gradient) (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Describe how to use a potometer to compare transpiration rates and name two controlled variables. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Measure rate of bubble movement or water uptake over time (1 mark)
Ensure airtight seals and cut shoot under water (1 mark)
Control temperature/light intensity (any one) (1 mark)
Control wind speed/humidity (any one) (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Describe the structure of phloem tissue relevant to translocation. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Sieve tube elements with sieve plates for flow (1 mark)
Companion cells with many mitochondria for active transport (1 mark)
Plasmodesmata connect companion cells and sieve elements (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Outline the mass flow hypothesis for translocation from source to sink. [5 marks]
mark_scheme: Sucrose actively loaded into sieve tubes at sources (1 mark)
Lowers water potential, water enters by osmosis (1 mark)
Increased hydrostatic pressure drives bulk flow (1 mark)
At sinks sucrose is unloaded/used or stored (1 mark)
Water leaves sieve tubes, reducing pressure at sinks (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Give three experimental evidences for translocation in phloem. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Aphid stylet analysis shows high sucrose in phloem sap (1 mark)
Radioactive 14C tracing tracks movement of assimilates (1 mark)
Ringing (removing bark) prevents sugar transport below the ring (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Define source and sink in phloem transport and give one example of each. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Source: site of sucrose production/export (e.g., mature leaf) (1 mark)
Sink: site of sucrose use/storage (e.g., root/tuber/fruit) (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Compare symplast and apoplast pathways for phloem loading. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Symplast: sucrose moves cell-to-cell via plasmodesmata (1 mark)
Apoplast: sucrose moves through cell walls and is actively transported into sieve elements (1 mark)
Apoplast loading uses H+–sucrose cotransport by companion cells (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Explain two adaptations of companion cells for active phloem loading. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Many mitochondria to supply ATP (1 mark)
High surface area and transporter density for sucrose/H+ movement (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: A plant stem is ringed to remove phloem but not xylem. Predict effects above and below the ring. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Sucrose accumulates above the ring causing swelling (1 mark)
Tissues below the ring are deprived of sugars and may die (1 mark)
Water transport continues as xylem remains intact (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Explain why phloem transport can be bidirectional whereas xylem flow is generally unidirectional. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Phloem moves from multiple sources to multiple sinks depending on demand (1 mark)
Xylem flow is driven by transpiration pull from roots to leaves (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: State and explain one effect of increased temperature on translocation rate. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Translocation rate increases up to an optimum (1 mark)
Higher temperature enhances enzyme activity and reduces sap viscosity (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Describe the pathway of water from the soil to the leaf air spaces. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Absorbed by root hairs into cortex via apoplast/symplast pathways (1 mark)
Crosses endodermis (Casparian strip forces symplastic entry) to xylem (1 mark)
Transported up xylem by cohesion–tension (1 mark)
Moves into mesophyll cell walls and evaporates into air spaces (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Explain how increasing arterial plaque formation (atherosclerosis) affects mass transport to tissues. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Narrows lumen and reduces blood flow (1 mark)
Increases resistance and may decrease oxygen delivery (1 mark)
Risk of thrombosis further obstructs tissue perfusion (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Suggest three mechanisms that increase venous return during exercise. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Skeletal muscle pump compresses veins (1 mark)
Deeper, faster breathing enhances thoracic pump (1 mark)
Sympathetic venoconstriction reduces venous capacity (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Why does haemoglobin with a left-shifted dissociation curve suit organisms at high altitude? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Higher affinity enhances O2 loading at low partial pressures (1 mark)
Improves arterial oxygenation in hypoxic conditions (1 mark)

3.3.4 Mass transport.question: Explain, with two points, why apoplastic phloem loading requires metabolic energy. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: H+-ATPase pumps protons to create an electrochemical gradient (1 mark)
Sucrose–H+ cotransport into companion/sieve cells is secondary active transport (1 mark)

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: Define a gene. [1 mark]

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: Define the terms genome and proteome. [2 marks]

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: Define the term locus. [1 mark]

Nucleosomes coil to form chromatin fibres (1 mark)
Chromatin condenses into visible chromosomes during cell division (1 mark)

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: Contrast DNA in eukaryotes and prokaryotes. Give three differences. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Eukaryotes: linear DNA associated with histones; prokaryotes: circular DNA not associated with histones (1 mark)
Eukaryotic DNA in nucleus; prokaryotic DNA in cytoplasm (nucleoid region) (1 mark)
Prokaryotes often have plasmids; eukaryotic nuclear DNA does not (1 mark)

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: State two features of mitochondrial or chloroplast DNA. [2 marks]

Contains genes for some organelle proteins/tRNAs/rRNAs (1 mark)

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: What is a plasmid? [1 mark]

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: Define a chromosome. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A DNA–protein structure carrying genes; a single long DNA molecule with associated proteins (1 mark)

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: Explain what is meant by homologous chromosomes. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: A pair of chromosomes with the same genes at the same loci (1 mark)

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: Distinguish between haploid and diploid. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Haploid: one set of chromosomes (n) (1 mark)
Diploid: two sets of homologous chromosomes (2n) (1 mark)

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: Explain why the genetic code is described as degenerate and state one advantage of degeneracy. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: More than one codon can specify the same amino acid (1 mark)
Reduces impact of some base substitutions (silent mutations) (1 mark)

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: What is meant by the genetic code being non-overlapping and read in a fixed reading frame? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Each base is part of only one codon; codons read sequentially (1 mark)
Reading frame set by start codon and maintained in triplets (1 mark)

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: Define introns and exons. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Exons are coding sequences that remain in mature mRNA (1 mark)

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: State the functional difference between a gene coding for a polypeptide and a gene coding for functional RNA. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Polypeptide genes specify amino acid sequences of proteins (1 mark)
Functional RNA genes produce RNA molecules (e.g., rRNA, tRNA) that are not translated (1 mark)

3.4.1 DNA, genes and chromosomes.question: Describe the basic structure of a nucleosome. [2 marks]

Linked by short stretches of linker DNA, often with H1 (1 mark)

mark_scheme: Electron transport pumps H⁺ into thylakoid lumen creating a high proton concentration (1 mark)
Photolysis adds more H⁺ to the lumen (1 mark)

Flow of H⁺ drives ATP formation from ADP + Pi (1 mark)

mark_scheme: Dissipates proton gradient across inner membrane (1 mark)
ATP synthase activity falls; less ATP produced (1 mark)
Electron transport and O₂ consumption increase; energy released as heat (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: List the stages of aerobic respiration in order and their cellular locations. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Glycolysis – cytosol (1 mark)
Link reaction – mitochondrial matrix (1 mark)
Krebs cycle – mitochondrial matrix (1 mark)
Oxidative phosphorylation – inner mitochondrial membrane/cristae (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Explain why the total ATP yield per glucose is an estimate rather than a fixed number. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Some energy is lost due to proton leak/maintenance transport (e.g., ADP/Pi/pyruvate) (1 mark)
P/O ratios vary; not all reduced coenzymes lead to the same ATP yield (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: State two stages of respiration where decarboxylation occurs. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Link reaction (pyruvate to acetyl-CoA) (1 mark)
Krebs cycle (e.g., isocitrate → α-ketoglutarate; α-ketoglutarate → succinyl-CoA) (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Give three features of the mitochondrial matrix that support the link reaction and Krebs cycle. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Contains enzymes for link/Krebs reactions (1 mark)
Contains NAD/FAD, mitochondrial DNA and ribosomes (1 mark)
Provides a suitable environment for enzyme function (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Explain why fatty acids yield more ATP per gram than carbohydrates when respired aerobically. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Fatty acids are more reduced (more C–H bonds) (1 mark)
β-oxidation produces many acetyl-CoA units (1 mark)
Generates more reduced NAD/FAD feeding the ETC (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Outline how amino acids can be used as respiratory substrates. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Deamination removes amino group (excreted as urea) (1 mark)
Carbon skeleton converted to pyruvate/acetyl-CoA/Krebs intermediates (1 mark)
Then enters respiration pathways to produce ATP (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Define dehydrogenation in the context of respiration. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Removal of hydrogen (electrons/protons) from a substrate, reducing NAD or FAD (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: How many turns of the Krebs cycle occur per molecule of glucose and why? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Two turns, because one glucose produces two acetyl-CoA (via two pyruvate) (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Give two experimental observations that support the chemiosmotic theory. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Proton gradients across membranes correlate with ATP synthesis (1 mark)
Uncouplers abolish ATP production without stopping electron flow (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Describe how to calculate oxygen uptake rate from respirometer data. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Determine capillary cross-sectional area and measure movement distance to get volume change (A × d) (1 mark)
Divide volume change by time to get rate (cm³ min⁻¹) (1 mark)
Correct using a control/temperature compensation if needed (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Explain why lactate accumulation can cause muscle fatigue and how lactate is dealt with after exercise. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Lactate lowers pH, inhibiting enzymes and contraction (1 mark)
Transported in blood to the liver (1 mark)
Oxidised back to pyruvate or converted to glucose using oxygen (oxygen debt) (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Compare lactate fermentation with alcoholic fermentation in terms of end products and reversibility. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Lactate vs ethanol + CO₂ (1 mark)
Both regenerate NAD from reduced NAD (1 mark)
Lactate can be reconverted to pyruvate; ethanol pathway is effectively irreversible in animals (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: State the number of carbon atoms in each: glucose, pyruvate, acetyl-CoA, citrate, oxaloacetate. [5 marks]
mark_scheme: Glucose = 6C (1 mark)
Pyruvate = 3C (1 mark)
Acetyl-CoA (acetyl group) = 2C (1 mark)
Citrate = 6C (1 mark)
Oxaloacetate = 4C (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Explain the role of mitochondrial DNA and ribosomes in respiration. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: mtDNA encodes some ETC/ATP synthase subunits and RNAs (1 mark)
Mitochondrial ribosomes synthesise some inner-membrane proteins in situ (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Describe how ATP and ADP/Pi are exchanged between the mitochondrial matrix and cytosol. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: ATP/ADP exchange via an antiporter in the inner membrane (1 mark)
Pi imported with H⁺ via a symporter (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Explain why FAD contributes fewer ATP than NAD when oxidised in the ETC. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: FAD feeds electrons into the ETC at complex II (1 mark)
Bypasses the first proton pump, so fewer protons are pumped and less ATP is made (1 mark)

3.5.2 Respiration.question: Predict the effect of inhibiting ATP synthase on the rates of electron transport and oxygen consumption. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Proton gradient builds up without being used (1 mark)
Back-pressure slows electron flow through the ETC (1 mark)
Oxygen consumption decreases because electrons cannot reach oxygen efficiently (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Define a trophic level. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A feeding level/position in a food chain or web (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Define biomass. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: The mass of living material in an organism or area, often as dry mass (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: State the relationship between gross primary productivity (GPP), net primary productivity (NPP) and respiratory losses (R) in producers. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: NPP = GPP − R (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Give the usual units for primary productivity measured over an area. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹ (or kJ m⁻² year⁻¹) (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: State two reasons why only a small percentage of the sun’s energy is fixed by producers. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Much light is the wrong wavelength, reflected or passes through leaves (1 mark)
Limiting factors such as CO₂ concentration or temperature reduce photosynthesis (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Describe how to estimate the dry biomass of a plant sample. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Heat a known fresh mass at low temperature to constant mass to remove water (1 mark)
Weigh after repeated drying and cooling in a desiccator to obtain dry mass (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Explain two reasons why pyramids of energy are always upright. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Energy is lost between trophic levels through respiration and heat (1 mark)
Not all biomass is consumed or assimilated by the next trophic level (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Define secondary productivity in animals. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: The rate at which consumers convert ingested food energy into new biomass (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: State two limitations of using fresh mass instead of dry mass to estimate biomass. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Water content varies between individuals and conditions (1 mark)
Gives inconsistent, non-comparable measures across samples (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Give two reasons for energy loss between producer and primary consumer trophic levels. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Herbivores cannot digest all plant tissue (cellulose/lignin) so energy lost in faeces (1 mark)
Respiratory heat losses for movement and maintaining temperature (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: A grassland has GPP = 9000 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹ and plant respiration R = 3800 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹. Calculate NPP. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: NPP = 9000 − 3800 = 5200 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹ (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Producer biomass is 4000 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹; primary consumer biomass is 800 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹. Calculate the efficiency of energy transfer to the primary consumer. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Efficiency = (energy in trophic level / energy in previous level) × 100 (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Define net production (N) in consumers and state the formula. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Net chemical energy in consumer biomass (1 mark)
N = I − (F + R), where I is ingested, F is faeces/egestion, R is respiration (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: A caterpillar ingests 1200 kJ, loses 500 kJ in faeces and 600 kJ in respiration. Calculate its net production and transfer efficiency to its biomass. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Use N = I − (F + R) (1 mark)
Efficiency = (100 ÷ 1200) × 100 = 8.3% (approx) (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Explain two farming practices that reduce respiratory losses in livestock to increase energy conversion efficiency. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Restrict movement or keep animals in warm conditions to reduce heat loss and respiration (1 mark)
Selective breeding/antibiotics to reduce disease and maintenance energy costs (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Give two ways in which intensive crop farming increases NPP. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Use of fertilisers/irrigation to remove nutrient/water limitations (1 mark)
Greenhouses or pest control to maximise photosynthesis and reduce losses to herbivores (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: State two ethical or environmental issues associated with intensive animal production. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Poor animal welfare due to confinement/restricted behaviour (1 mark)
Waste pollution/antibiotic resistance or higher greenhouse gas emissions (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Describe the role of decomposers in energy flow and nutrient recycling. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Saprobionts secrete enzymes to break down dead organic matter (1 mark)
Release inorganic ions to the soil and energy as heat during respiration (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Explain why food chains rarely have more than four or five trophic levels. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Large energy losses at each transfer (low efficiency) (1 mark)
Insufficient energy remains to support higher trophic levels (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Give two advantages of using pyramids of biomass rather than numbers. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Reflects actual amount of living tissue/energy better than counts (1 mark)
Avoids anomalies where few large organisms support many small ones (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Outline how bomb calorimetry can estimate the energy content of biomass. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Burn a known dry mass of sample in an oxygen-rich chamber immersed in water (1 mark)
Measure temperature rise of a known mass of water (1 mark)
Calculate energy released using q = mcΔT and express per gram (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Describe two reasons why field estimates of productivity can be imprecise. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Sampling error/spatial heterogeneity of vegetation (1 mark)
Temporal changes in growth and respiration over seasons (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Explain why endotherms typically have lower production efficiency than ectotherms. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Endotherms use more energy for thermoregulation (1 mark)
Higher respiratory heat losses reduce energy available for growth (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: A crop field has NPP of 6000 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹. Pests consume 20% of NPP, and harvesting removes 70% of what remains. How much energy is transferred to humans via the crop per m² per year? [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Energy after pests = 6000 × 0.80 = 4800 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹ (1 mark)
Harvest removes 70% of 4800 = 3360 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹ (1 mark)
Answer: 3360 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹ (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Explain two ways biological control can improve energy transfer to humans compared with broad-spectrum pesticides. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Targets specific pests reducing non-target losses and maintaining pollinators (1 mark)
Reduces chemical resistance and repeated applications, conserving ecosystem services (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Give three typical pathways by which consumers lose assimilated energy. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Respiration and heat production (1 mark)
Excretion/urine and egestion/faeces (1 mark)
Repair and maintenance activities or thermoregulation (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: State three adaptations of crops and farm practices that increase light interception and GPP. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: High leaf area index/canopy density via close planting (1 mark)
Use of early-maturing or high-chlorophyll cultivars (1 mark)
Row orientation/greenhouses to optimise light exposure (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: In an aquatic mesocosm, primary productivity is reported in kJ m⁻³ yr⁻¹ rather than kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹. Explain why. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Water column has depth so volume better represents producing space (1 mark)
Productivity depends on light penetration and biomass throughout the volume (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: A primary consumer assimilates 600 kJ from 1200 kJ ingested and has R = 450 kJ. Calculate its net production and production efficiency relative to assimilation. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: N = I − (F + R) and I − F = assimilation = 600 kJ (1 mark)
Net production = 600 − 450 = 150 kJ (1 mark)
Production efficiency (to biomass) = 150 ÷ 600 × 100 = 25% (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Suggest two reasons why NPP is usually higher in warm, moist climates than in cold, dry ones. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Higher enzyme activity and longer growing seasons at warm temperatures (1 mark)
Adequate water supports stomatal opening and CO₂ uptake/photosynthesis (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Explain why constant-temperature drying is necessary when determining dry mass. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Ensures only water is removed without combusting organic matter (1 mark)
Allows mass to reach a stable constant value for accuracy (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Describe how simplifying a food web can increase the efficiency of energy transfer to humans. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Reduce number of trophic levels between producer and humans (1 mark)
Control pests and weeds to reduce losses from producers (1 mark)
More energy reaches human food as plant biomass or primary consumer biomass (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Define assimilation in the context of consumer energetics. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: The portion of ingested energy that is absorbed and available after egestion losses (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Give four reasons for variation in energy transfer efficiency between habitats or taxa. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Digestibility of food (cellulose vs protein) and gut morphology (1 mark)
Thermoregulatory strategy (ectotherm vs endotherm) (1 mark)
Activity level and movement costs (1 mark)
Environmental temperature and water availability affecting metabolism (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Explain how intercropping can increase overall productivity compared with monoculture. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Different species exploit resources (light, nutrients) at different times/depths (1 mark)
Reduces pest outbreaks by disrupting host continuity (1 mark)
Higher total NPP due to complementary resource use (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: A pyramid of biomass shows 250 g m⁻² at producers, 50 g m⁻² at primary consumers, and 5 g m⁻² at secondary consumers. Calculate efficiency from producers to primary consumers and from primary to secondary consumers. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: State formula used each time (1 mark)
Correct units understanding or ratios described (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Outline an investigation to compare above-ground NPP in fertilised vs unfertilised plots. [5 marks]
mark_scheme: Randomly assign replicate plots to fertilised and control treatments (1 mark)
Measure initial biomass proxy (e.g., non-destructive allometry) or standardise planting (1 mark)
At season end, harvest above-ground biomass, dry to constant mass (1 mark)
Calculate NPP as increase in dry mass per area per time (1 mark)
Analyse difference statistically (e.g., t-test) (1 mark)

3.5.3 Energy and ecosystems.question: Discuss three trade-offs of intensive aquaculture with respect to energy efficiency and sustainability. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: High conversion efficiency when using ectothermic fish vs terrestrial livestock (1 mark)
Feed inputs (fishmeal/soy) may reduce net global energy efficiency (1 mark)
Waste and eutrophication risks from high stocking densities (1 mark)
Disease transmission requiring treatments or vaccines (1 mark)
Selective breeding and recirculating systems can improve FCR and reduce impacts (1 mark)
Energy costs of aeration, pumping and temperature control affect net gains (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Define a saprobiont. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A microorganism that feeds on dead organic matter by extracellular digestion (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Define ammonification. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Conversion of organic nitrogen (e.g., proteins/urea) into ammonium ions (NH4+) by saprobionts (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Define nitrification. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Aerobic oxidation of ammonium to nitrite (NO2−) and then to nitrate (NO3−) by nitrifying bacteria (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Name the bacteria typically involved in the two steps of nitrification. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Ammonium → nitrite: Nitrosomonas (or Nitrosococcus) (1 mark)
Nitrite → nitrate: Nitrobacter (or Nitrospira) (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Define nitrogen fixation. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Reduction of atmospheric N2 to ammonia/ammonium by nitrogen-fixing bacteria (or industrially/lightning) (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Give two examples of nitrogen-fixing bacteria and where they are found. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Rhizobium in legume root nodules (symbiotic) (1 mark)
Azotobacter free-living in soil (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Explain the mutualistic relationship between Rhizobium and legumes. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Bacteria fix N2 to ammonium for amino acid synthesis in the plant (1 mark)
Plant supplies carbohydrates (photosynthate) to bacteria (1 mark)
Leghaemoglobin maintains low O2 to protect nitrogenase (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Describe conditions that favour denitrification and why this reduces soil fertility. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Waterlogged/anaerobic soils favour denitrifying bacteria (Pseudomonas) (1 mark)
Nitrate is reduced to N2/N2O gases, removing available nitrogen from soil (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Outline the sequence of reactions in denitrification. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: NO3− → NO2− (1 mark)
NO2− → NO (nitric oxide) or N2O (nitrous oxide) (1 mark)
NO/N2O → N2 (released to atmosphere) (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Explain why ploughing/aerating soil can reduce denitrification. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Introduces oxygen, making soil aerobic (1 mark)
Inhibits anaerobic denitrifiers and promotes aerobic nitrifiers (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Summarise the main transfers in the phosphorus cycle. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Weathering releases phosphate ions (PO4^3−) from rocks to soil/water (1 mark)
Absorption by plants and transfer through food chains (1 mark)
Return via excretion and decomposition by saprobionts (1 mark)
Sedimentation to new rocks in aquatic systems (long-term store) (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Explain the role of mycorrhizae in plant mineral nutrition. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Fungal hyphae increase effective root surface area (1 mark)
Enhance uptake of phosphate and water (especially in poor soils) (1 mark)
Mutualism: fungus receives sugars from the plant (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Describe how nitrate taken up by roots is assimilated into organic nitrogen in plants. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: NO3− reduced to NO2− then to NH4+ (1 mark)
NH4+ incorporated into amino acids via glutamine/glutamate pathways (1 mark)
Enzymes include nitrate reductase and nitrite reductase (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Outline the stages of eutrophication caused by nitrate fertiliser run-off. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Leaching of nitrates increases aquatic nutrient levels (1 mark)
Rapid algal bloom increases turbidity (1 mark)
Light penetration falls; plants die; decomposers increase (1 mark)
Oxygen depleted → fish/invertebrate deaths; potential dead zones (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Suggest three farming practices to reduce nitrate leaching. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Apply fertiliser in smaller, timed doses during active growth (1 mark)
Use buffer strips/cover crops to trap nutrients (1 mark)
Avoid spreading before heavy rain; incorporate fertiliser into soil (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Compare natural (organic) and artificial (inorganic) fertilisers. Give two pros/cons overall. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Organic: slow release, improves soil structure/microbiota (1 mark)
Inorganic: precise nutrient ratios, rapid availability (1 mark)
Organic: variable composition/volume, possible pathogens/odour (1 mark)
Inorganic: higher leaching risk/eutrophication, no improvement to soil humus (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: State two environmental problems linked to overuse of nitrogen fertilisers. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Leaching leading to eutrophication (1 mark)
Emission of nitrous oxide (greenhouse gas) or acidification (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: A farmer applies 150 kg N ha−1. Plants take up 90 kg N ha−1; 40 kg N ha−1 is leached. Calculate the percentage to uptake, leaching, and other losses. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Other losses (e.g., gaseous/immobilisation): 100 − 60 − 26.7 ≈ 13.3% (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Explain the role of extracellular enzymes in decomposition. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Saprobionts secrete enzymes to hydrolyse polymers (e.g., proteins, cellulose) (1 mark)
Soluble products are absorbed and mineral ions released to soil (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Distinguish between mineralisation and immobilisation in soils. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Mineralisation: conversion of organic nutrients to inorganic ions (1 mark)
Immobilisation: microbial uptake of inorganic ions into biomass (1 mark)
Balance controls nutrient availability to plants (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Explain why waterlogged soils often accumulate NH4+ but lose NO3−. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Anaerobic conditions inhibit aerobic nitrification (1 mark)
Denitrification reduces NO3− to N gases (1 mark)
Ammonium persists due to limited oxidation to nitrite/nitrate (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Describe the microbial succession during composting that accelerates nutrient recycling. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Mesophiles start breakdown; temperature rises (1 mark)
Thermophiles dominate; rapid degradation of proteins/cell walls (1 mark)
Cooling phase with maturation and humus formation (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Outline how superphosphate fertiliser is produced from phosphate rock. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Treat phosphate rock with sulfuric or phosphoric acid (1 mark)
Produces soluble calcium dihydrogen phosphate for plant uptake (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Give two reasons phosphate is often limiting in freshwater ecosystems. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Phosphate strongly adsorbs to soil particles/sediments (low solubility) (1 mark)
Slow recycling from sediments/rocks compared with nitrogen (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Explain how seabird guano influences the phosphorus cycle on islands/coasts. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Guano deposits add concentrated phosphate to soils (1 mark)
Enhances primary productivity and plant growth locally (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Suggest two ways intensive aquaculture can contribute to eutrophication. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Uneaten feed/fish waste enrich water with N and P (1 mark)
Effluent discharge increases algal blooms downstream (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Why is spring application of nitrogen fertiliser preferable to winter application in temperate regions? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Coincides with active plant growth and uptake (1 mark)
Reduces winter leaching during high rainfall/low uptake (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Explain why mycorrhizae are especially beneficial in phosphorus-poor or dry soils. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Extend hyphal network into soil micropores to access scarce PO4^3− (1 mark)
Improve water uptake, reducing drought stress (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Describe how some denitrifying bacteria use nitrate in anaerobic respiration. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Use NO3− as terminal electron acceptor instead of O2 (1 mark)
Reduce NO3− to NO/N2O/N2, generating ATP (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Trace the nitrogen pathway from a dead animal to plant amino acids. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Decomposition and ammonification → NH4+ (1 mark)
Nitrification to NO2− then NO3− (aerobic bacteria) (1 mark)
Root uptake of nitrate by plants (1 mark)
Assimilation into amino acids/proteins (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Explain how including legumes in crop rotations can reduce fertiliser requirements. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Rhizobium fix N2 adding organic N to soil (1 mark)
Residues/roots increase soil nitrogen for subsequent crops (1 mark)
Improves soil structure and microbial activity (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: State two potential effects of over-liming soils on nutrient availability. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Phosphate can precipitate with Ca2+ reducing availability (1 mark)
Micronutrient availability (e.g., Fe, Mn) may decrease at high pH (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Why is geological recycling of phosphorus considered slow compared with nitrogen? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: P has major reservoirs in rocks/sediments requiring weathering (1 mark)
No atmospheric gaseous phase analogous to N2 (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Give one role where fungi are particularly important in decomposition relative to bacteria. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Efficient degradation of lignin/woody tissues (1 mark)
Penetrate substrates with hyphae increasing enzyme access (1 mark)
Operate at lower moisture/pH ranges in litter layers (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: A river’s nitrate concentration rises from 20 mg L−1 to 60 mg L−1 after rainfall. Calculate the percentage increase. [1 mark]
Explain how vegetated buffer strips beside waterways reduce eutrophication risk. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Trap sediments and adsorb nitrate/phosphate before runoff enters streams (1 mark)
Promote denitrification/uptake within the buffer vegetation and soils (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Describe why ploughing a long-fallowed field can cause a temporary ‘nitrogen flush’. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Aeration stimulates microbial activity (1 mark)
Rapid mineralisation of organic N to NH4+ and nitrification to NO3− (1 mark)
Short-term rise in plant-available N followed by potential leaching (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Explain how soil phosphatase enzymes aid plant phosphorus acquisition. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Hydrolyse organic P compounds to release inorganic PO4^3− (1 mark)
Produced by roots and microbes, increasing available P near rhizosphere (1 mark)

3.5.4 Nutrient cycles.question: Evaluate the trade-offs of applying organic manures as a nutrient source. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Adds N, P, K with slow release matching crop demand (1 mark)
Improves soil structure, water holding, and microbial diversity (1 mark)
Variable nutrient content; requires larger volumes/logistics (1 mark)
Potential pathogen/weed seed load and odour (1 mark)
Risk of leaching/runoff if over-applied or before rain (1 mark)
Can reduce reliance on synthetic fertilisers and recycle waste (1 mark)
